item.title: Consider Phlebas
item.description:
How would you like to experience the scale and fun of the world of Star Wars movies in a novel? Consider Phlebas is the first true space opera novel that I read. Written by science fiction author Iain M. Banks, in this story we journey around space with a bunch of mercenaries while the universe around them is caught up in an epic war between the Idirans and Culture.

Our protagonist is Horza, a shape-changing changer on the side of the Idirans who is in pursuit of a Culture Mind that is hiding on Schar's World. Escaping from Perosteck Balveda, a Culture spy, he hides his true identity and joins a group of pirates led by Kraiklyn on their ship Clear Air Turbulence (CAT). The raid of this gang on the Temple of Light ends up a disaster when their plasma shots bounce off the crystal walls of the temple. To recoup his losses, Kraiklyn decides to take part in the Damage card game being held on the orbital Vavatch before it is destroyed by Culture. While they are there, they decide to steal weapons from an abandoned mega ship named Olmedreca. This raid turns out to be a disaster too, killing most of the crew and Horza crashing on a remote island on the Vavatch.

He is held prisoner by a cult of Eaters and their guru Fwi-Song. Using his special powers, he escapes in the nick of time and returns to witness Kraiklyn's wager in the epic game of Damage. Kraiklyn loses the game badly and during his escape Horza kills him and takes on his shape. He rejoins the reminder of the CAT gang as their leader and along with smart-talking drone Unaha-Clasp and Balveda.

They blast their way out of the Culture ship The Ends of Invention and set a course to Schar's World. They discover that the mind is hiding in the tunnels of The Command System of this world. A renegade bunch of Idirans trouble them and in the final battle Horza dies and the Mind escapes.

This is truly a delicious start to the Culture space opera series and it is real fun to journey to new worlds in search of adventure with a bunch of pirates. The characters are colorful, and the new spaceships and worlds are awe-inspiring and interesting. The novel is really strong in the first act, gets weaker in the second and fizzles out in the long-drawn out third. The author has a great knack for creating incredibly interesting, but unnecessary sideplots, like the Eaters or the Damage card game. Furthermore, the reason behind the Idirans-Culture war is all a bit vague and so are the powers of the Mind. Though I complain, I loved the good parts and I might read the second book in the series.

Rating: 3/5

item.title: Nehru Bal Pustakalaya
item.description:
Flipping through the news from India I noticed that a prominent astrophysicist Jayant Narlikar had passed away recently. That name seemed vaguely familiar from my childhood and with a little digging I re-discovered that he was the author of one of my favorite childhood books A Journey through the Universe. This was one of the many fantastic children's books from the Nehru Bal Pustakalaya collection that were a large part of my early years.

I first discovered these books when my school had a book fair organized by their publisher National Book Trust. It was a thrilling and unique experience to see a part of your school transform into a book fair for a few days, to get some cash from parents, to sample and shop the books alone or with friends (without parent supervision) and to make the crucial decision on which few books to buy with the limited amount of cash. The few books I bought in this way felt so precious, the feel of that rough paper, the smell of freshness, that iconic rose logo at the top-left corner of each book cover and the beautiful illustrations by Sudhir Dar. I would read these books a thousand times over and they truly showed me what a wonderful world I inhabited.

These books stood out in that era with their style, with each book having its own unique cover and inner art. Also, rare for that era, these were full color covers, not limited 2 or 3 bland shades, but shockingly bright colors in their full glory. Jayant Karlikar's book and the 2-part Inventions that changed the world by Najabat Ali remain the most memorable of the lot to me with superb funny cartoons by Sudhir Dar. These books covered pretty much the every swath of science, from physics to scientists, giving me a taste of things that lay beyond the little world in India of the 80s.

item.title: Becoming Earth
item.description:
We think of our planet as being shaped by Sun, weather, water, earthquakes, volcanoes and geological processes. In Becoming Earth, the science writer Ferris Jabr tries to show evidence that in addition to the above, our planet has always been shaped by microbes, plant and animal life too. Divided into 3 parts on rock, water and air, each part looks at the author's journeys to various parts of Earth to meet scientists who have discovered fascinating ways in which life shaped and continues to affect Earth.

In the first part on Rock, we travel to deep caves and mines to discover how microbes deep inside the Earth's crust have been chewing through rocks to break them down into soil for millions of years. We travel to the frozen Russian steppe to learn how the stomping around by now-extinct mammoths there might have helped grass emerge from the megafauna of that period. Finally, we visit the author's own backyard in Oregon where he and his partner were able to coax a diversity of plants to grow out of rock-hard ground thanks to the power of the roots of specific plants.

In the second part on Water, we discover the massive scale of plankton in the seas and how they affect marine life and the carbon in the atmosphere. Off the coast of California, we learn about the effect of scale of seaweed and kelp forests in the oceans and how they help in sequestering massive amounts of carbon. Finally, we travel to Kamilo Beach in Hawaii where the planet's plastic trash has been washing up and creating new substrates by fusing with rock.

In the final part on Air, we travel to Brazil to climb the Amazon Tall Tower Observatory to learn how the tall trees of the Amazon and microbes that produce proteins seed ice crystals in clouds and cause rain. In California, we learn how Native Americans uses controlled burns as a land management tool to shape their forests and allow a diversity of fauna to flourish.

This was a delicious well-researched book to read, with the author being adept at weaving together travels to exotic places,scientists, historical events and discoveries together. There are a good set of color photos in the book to aid the narration. There is no doubt that microbes, plants, animals and especially humans have changed the atmosphere and the planet. While it is evident that microbes, plankton and human industrialization can have massive effects, many of the other cases presented by the author (such as megafauna, plastic on a beach) are weaker and sometimes unrelated to the agenda of the book. And as always, I am skeptical of science writers and prefer such books to be written by actual scientists, who are usually far more skeptical and far less flowery in the praise of evidence. Regardless, this book easily takes the reader on a fascinating journey in time and space around the world showing us the wonders of our planet.

Rating: 3/5

item.title: Happiness Falls
item.description:
How a family of a special needs child deals with the disappearance of their father is at the center of Happiness Falls. We learn about the disappearance through the voice of Mia, the daughter of a Korean mother (Hannah Park) and a white father (Adam Parson). Her younger brother Eugene, who has speech and movement impairments (Angelman Syndrome) had accompanied Adam to a nearby state park and returned home alone. Mia mistakenly assumes her dad is at home and several precious hours are lost before the police are called and a missing person search is started. As detective Janus probes into the hours before the disappearance she discovers that Eugene might have attacked his father in a burst of anger that morning. At the same time, Mia digs into her dad's life and discovers that he and Eugene had been seeing a therapist Anjeli Rapari in secret. As the hours turn into days, the family is drawn into a legal custody battle while also discovering uncomfortable and surprising things about themselves.

The author Angie Kim deftly keeps many balls in the air at the same time - a super intriguing mystery, Asian family drama, and special needs children and their impact on a relationship and family. The book is extremely detailed about the caring, terminology, treatments and upbringing of special needs children. Some great analogies are provided in the book about how society fails to appreciate Eugene's intelligence since it is hidden behind his motor and speech impediments. The author easily takes the reader on a ride, making me believe that Adam was having an affair with Anjeli. The weakest part of the book is probably the over-emphasis on Adam's notes on Happiness Quotient (HQ). Nevertheless, Angie is a tour de force here, crafting a meticulous, intriguing and sensitive tale.

Rating: 4/5

Excerpts

I don’t understand people who pop out of sleep at the first alarm. I love snoozing. A push of a button, elongating the surreal haze of that liminal phase, letting me linger in the delicious afterglow of the dream world where anything is possible, where I can think something and it’s suddenly there the next moment, no transition, no explanation, no logic. It’s like sitting in the theater after a great movie has ended, listening to the score as the credits scroll, giving you time to reflect before you head back to the real world.

As Mom likes to point out, it’s fascinating how it’s called “retirement” when fathers quit their jobs, but “becoming a stay-at-home mom” when mothers do.

She stopped doing therapy homework with Eugene, said she wanted to accept Eugene—“as he is, with no expectations.” (But, as Dad always pointed out, how can you not have expectations of a child? What is a child if not as-yet-unrealized potential personified?)

There are moments when something we’ve idealized all our lives changes and becomes something less. Not by a noticeable amount, just an infinitesimal disappointment. But it’s like going from 100 percent to 99.9 percent—imperceptible quantitatively, but dramatically different qualitatively, from flawless to flawed. After this point, I found myself questioning Dad’s motives, doubting his perspectives, in a way I hadn’t before.

Have you ever had your parents teach/tutor you (or, if you’re a parent, tried to teach/tutor your own child)? In my family’s experience, it’s torture, ending in raised voices and tears for everyone involved. I don’t know what it is, but everything my parents said, even (maybe especially) if delivered gently and lovingly, I couldn’t help but take personally—as an expression of disappointment, a buried wish they had a different child. It made me vacillate between trying too hard, desperate to impress, and refusing to cooperate and giving up, both to cope with the anxiety overload and to punish them for putting me into that state to begin with. If getting better at math or baseball was this fraught, I couldn’t imagine practicing communication with a nonspeaking child—the expectations, the fears, the anxiety magnified ten thousandfold.

Of course you will and can want more. You should want more. But you should also spend time trying to want what you already have. It’s slightly different from “practicing gratitude” or appreciating or thanking a higher force or God for what you have. It means: Don’t let what you already have be the baseline. Think of yourself before you gained what you have, and remind yourself how much you want that, what you already have—your spouse/partner, your family, your house, your job. Imagine you in an alternate universe where you don’t have your family, can’t have your kids or your partner, how desperate that alternate-you would be to get what you have.

item.title: On Tyranny
item.description:
On Tyranny is a tiny book written by Timothy Snyder containing 20 recommendations for citizens to face up to tyranny. The word tyranny can mean different things to different people, but this book is focused on facing up to "the usurpation of power by a single individual or group, or the circumvention of law by rulers for their own benefit". Published in 2017 and seemingly updated a few years later, it is actually focused on what is happening politically in the US at this moment.

The author seems to have expertise in the 1900-1950s rise of communism and fascism in Europe, how Germans let Hitler rise in power and stood by watching as he grabbed all power and committed atrocities on Jews. So, he applies learnings from that part of the world history to present-day USA and offers 20 succinct recommendations. The book though has blinders - it does not recognize that dictators or fascists do not rise in power in a vacuum and that they become an attractive option to people who have genuine problems in life. So what to do after a tyranny is prevented - unless a strong alternate solution is visible, the grieving people are unlikely to be moved.

I liked how dense and distilled the book reads, with every sentence terse and loaded with gravity. The book is of course a call to action and with its tiny size is a quick read. Being the size of a pocket book, it is also an easy book to carry around or gift to people.

Rating: 4/5

Excerpt

The 20 lessons:

  1. Do not obey in advance.
  2. Defend institutions.
  3. Beware the one-party state.
  4. Take responsibility for the face of the world.
  5. Remember professional ethics.
  6. Be wary of paramilitaries.
  7. Be reflective if you must be armed.
  8. Stand out.
  9. Be kind to our language.
  10. Believe in truth.
  11. Investigate.
  12. Make eye contact and small talk.
  13. Practice corporeal politics.
  14. Establish a private life.
  15. Contribute to good causes.
  16. Learn from peers in other countries.
  17. Listen for dangerous words.
  18. Be calm when the unthinkable arrives.
  19. Be a patriot.
  20. Be as courageous as you can.

item.title: The Verifiers
item.description:
The Verifiers goes for that (as yet) unique intersection of murder mystery, online dating and the Asian immigrant experience. In this debut novel by Jane Pek we follow the narration of protagonist Claudia Lin, a young New Yorker at her first job at a dating detective agency. A what? This strange business named Veracity handles investigation queries discreetly from online daters. Their client Iris Lettriste wants to know why a guy she was chatting with on a dating app suddenly stopped talking with her. Just when Claudia is biking around town and digging up the dirt on the mystery man, Iris is discovered dead at her apartment. Claudia is asked to drop the case by her bosses Komla Atsina and Becks Rittel, but she continues to pursue it out of her own interest and discovers a much bigger conspiracy at play.

The author brings to bear a deep knowledge of the dating app technology, the harvesting and sale of customer data, how users lie about themselves (the lying limitation) and the use of fake AI bots (synths). What is also great is the Asian immigrant family dynamic, which absorbs a big part of the story, though unfortunately it has nothing to do with the plot. The author nails Claudia's interactions with her siblings Charlie and Caroline and especially with her never-quite-satisfied mother. Where the novel fails is the murder mystery itself, which is just not interesting enough. I felt like I was plodding through intense dating company business details and Asian family drama in the latter 2 acts, all in the pursuit of a murder which was not meh. There are also too many references to some fictional Inspector Yuan mystery series and to local NYC places, neither of which I could care less about. And finally at the end of a drawn out 3rd act, you finally face the murderer and ask yourself "Really? This is it?".

Rating: 3/5

item.title: Malice
item.description:
It is no secret that I love the murder mysteries by Keigo Higashino. Malice is the first novel in his Police Detective Kaga series and the English translation is by Alexander O. Smith. Set in 1996, the plot opens with the mysterious murder of famous author Hidaka that is discovered by his new second wife Rie and his close friend Osamu Nonoguchi. As the investigation progresses, we get to read Osamu's journal entries and Kaga's testimonials that lead to the truth. There are many twists as Kaga proceeds to tear apart the initial hypothesis and delves far into Hidaka's childhood to solve the murder.

Like in most of Higashino's books, the murderer is found early on, but establishing how he committed the mysterious murder is the journey. In this book, there is also the added wrinkle of why - the motive which dogs Kaga, why was Hidaka killed? We learn that it was due to malice, but the details elude us until the final chapter.

The book is nail-biting, as always, and it took me just 2 sittings to finish it. My mind was engrossed in the multiple possibilities and motives until late in the night. I also liked the unique writing style of this particular book, as either journal entries or police reports, that really made me think harder. This is yet another perfect un-put-downable Higashino book, the only minor quibble being a bit too much time spent on the motive.

Rating: 4/5

Excerpts

"But your plan was unique. You had an entirely different goal in mind. You wanted to get arrested. You didn’t care about committing the perfect crime. You wanted to establish the perfect motive. I know. It’s a rather startling idea. You may be the first murderer that decided to fabricate a motive before committing the crime. Believe me, I almost couldn’t bring myself to accept the truth. During the long hours it took me to reach the point where I was confident I’d uncovered the truth, I doubted myself every step of the way. In fact, I refused to believe what the facts were telling me. Of course, had we questioned any of the evidence earlier then we might well have resolved this much more quickly. Yet who would suspect a killer of forging a vital piece of evidence indicating his own guilt of a crime? Truly, that was a brilliant stroke."

"It is an unfortunate fact that the police tend to turn a stern eye toward evidence that benefits a suspect, but tend to be rather easygoing when it comes to evidence that implicates our suspect. A tendency you deftly took advantage of."

item.title: The Light Eaters
item.description:
"For it was my master who taught me not only how very little I knew but also that any wisdom to which I might ever aspire could consist only in realizing more fully the infinity of my ignorance" -- Karl Popper

The infinity of my ignorance about plants further increased as I read The Light Eaters by Zoe Schlanger. This book looks at the spate of astonishing discoveries being made about plants in the last few decades that are showing how little we know about them.

The plants from my school science classes were essentially a green machine that grew from seeds, roots and leaves that used sunlight and water to produce our food. Scientists are now discovering that plants are able to communicate with each other, can feel touch, listen, have memory, interact actively with animals, can change themselves to mimic other plants, have a social life and even adapt to plants of their own kin. Zoe talks to the real scientific pioneers in the field of plant science, goes on scientific expeditions with them into jungles and describes the many strange and mysterious plants that are exhibiting these incredible behaviors.

The book demolished my notion that plants are boring. They are 80% by weight of the Earth's living matter and have been here before all animal life and will probably be still here after we are gone. Plants from millions of years ago, like ferns and gingko are still here with us. Ferns especially are insane beings, it was a revelation for me that they produce cork-screw sperm that swim in water to mate with female fern eggs!

We think of them as static, but they are in constant (slow) motion, probing air and soil to thrive. They certainly don't have brains, but seem to be able to sense, be aware and able to adapt to their environment. There is an entire field of phytoacoustics on how plants react to sounds. Or vernalization, where plants use their memory of winter to be able to sprout.

Plants also actively interact with animals, both being eaten and also as the predator. But mostly they coexist, sometimes even conscripting them (ants) to be their bodyguards, paying them with syrup and lodging. Probably the biggest star of the book is boquila, the chameleon vine, that can mimic the leaves of any host plant it swirls itself around! How can a plant do this unless there is some sight or genetic transfer at play?!

The popular book The Secret Life of Plants brought shame to this field, with its revelations that were non-scientific and non-reproducible. This book on the other hand is on stronger footing, with most of the findings being backed by solid science and real scientists. There are only a couple of instances where the author sympathizes with the point of view of some pseudo-scientists or philosophers, which I found unsettling. The biggest blunder in the book was the lack of pictures. I found myself looking up photos of every one of the mentioned plants and it boggles my mind why they couldn't put those in the book in the first place! Zoe is a great writer, able to wield the power of the language to draw the reader in and amaze us all over again about plants.

Rating: 4/5

item.title: Lieutenant Hornblower
item.description:
Lieutenant Hornblower is the second book in the Hornblower series by C. S. Forester. At the end of Mr. Midshipman Hornblower he was promoted to junior Lieutenant and that's where we find him here on the HMS Renown. He, a new senior lieutenant Bush and the first lieutenant Buckland are positively terrified by their insane captain Sawyer. A mutiny is almost in the plans when the captain falls down stairs and is paralyzed and taken insane. Buckland takes control of the ship and with the help of Bush and some ingenious thinking by Hornblower is able to plan, fight and defeat a Spanish coastal fort in the West Indies and take their ships. The captured Spanish erupt on the Renown, but are put down thanks to timely courageous action by Hornblower. Returning back to safe harbor, they are all tried in court and Hornblower is promoted to Commander of a smaller ship. But just before Hornblower can celebrate, the war with Napoleon ends in truce and all of them lose their jobs. Our protagonist ends up playing card games with naval officers at a club to make ends meet. Will Lady Luck shine on him again and lift him to his naval destiny?

Unlike the first book, which had multiple stories, this book has a single story and I liked that. The narration is from the point of view of Bush, so we get an unique perspective of how Hornblower is viewed by another lieutenant who, though initially wary of his pluck, learns to respect his vitality. The detailed military strategy hatched to capture the Spanish fort and tricks used to convince them to surrender are truly enjoyable to experience. A lot of the writing is also about the hierarchy of power on a ship, the ranks and duties of the officers and their difficulty in getting promoted. We are witness to how good fortune and bad luck can make or break an officer's life career. And here is something surprising: I think this work stands out as a great book on engineering management, not kidding. There was quite literally nothing I did not like in this second nail-biting naval adventure and I am eager for the next one.

Rating: 5/5

ISBN: 9780316289078

Excerpts

He was aware that naval officers could be divided into active individuals and passive individuals, into those eager for responsibility and action and into those content to wait until action was forced on them. Before that he had learned the simpler lesson that officers could be divided into the efficient and the blunderers, and also into the intelligent and the stupid — this last division was nearly the same as the one immediately preceding, but not quite. There were the officers who could be counted on to act quickly and correctly in an emergency, and those who could not — again the dividing line did not quite coincide with the preceding.

And in any case logical thinking on the subject of reputation and promotion was not easy, because during all these years Bush had become more and more imbued with the knowledge that the service was a hard and ungrateful one, in which fortune was even more capricious than in other walks of life. Good luck came and went in the navy as unpredictably as death chose its victims when a broadside swept a crowded deck.

Bush had learned something during the past few weeks which his service during the years had not called to his attention. In the ships of the line in which he had served there had only been minutes of battle for every week at sea, and he had gradually become fixed in the idea that seamanship was the one requisite for a naval officer. To be master of the countless details of managing a wooden sailing ship; not only to be able to handle her under sail, but to be conversant with all the petty but important trifles regarding cordage and cables, pumps and salt pork, dry rot and the Articles of War; that was what was necessary. But he knew now of other qualities equally necessary: a bold and yet thoughtful initiative, moral as well as physical courage, tactful handling both of superiors and of subordinates, ingenuity and quickness of thought. A fighting navy needed to fight, and needed fighting men to lead it.

item.title: Kids books we loved in 2025
item.description:
This is a collection of books that our kids loved to read this year.

Books loved by 9-year old

  • Guts (by Raina Telgemeier): Every graphic novel by this author is based on her personal life and it really shows in the kinds of detail she depicts. This one is quite mature, looking at how the relationship of the author evolved with her sister as their new brother joined their family.

  • Out of my Dreams (by Sharon M. Draper): Another followup to the Out of my Mind that my son read with rapt interest.

  • Out of my Heart (by Sharon M. Draper): Final book in the Out of my Mind series.

Books loved by 4-year old

  • And to Think That I Saw It On Mulberry Street (by Dr. Seuss): Apparently the very first book by Dr. Seuss. Incredible to imagine that he knocked it out of the park in the very first one. All his familiar strokes are already in his first book: inventive new words, rhyming story and great art.

  • Dr. Seuss's Sleep Book (by Dr. Seuss): Incredible inventive sleeptime rhyming poem.

  • The Lorax (by Dr. Seuss): Lorax, thneed and other amazing words in this pertinent story about nature and human greed.

item.title: Dragon Teeth
item.description:
Dragon Teeth is one of those posthumously published novels of Michael Crichton. Set in 1875, this story thrusts Yale University student William Johnson into the rivalry between paleontologists Marsh and Cope. Johnson signs on to Marsh's expedition for dinosaur bones and starts off on a long railroad journey from Philadelphia to the American West (Wyoming, Idaho and Montana). He soon learns that Marsh is an evil smooth-talking cut-throat and ends up joining Cope's expedition. Cope and his ragtag bunch of explorers are thrust into the midst of a war between the US Army and Native American tribes. They venture far into Native American territory on horseback and discover amazing new kinds of dinosaurs, even when thwarted by Marsh's henchmen. On the return, Johnson is separated with the precious boxes of bones and he endures a year long story of survival in dangerous Wild West towns filled with insane trigger-happy shooters.

Apparently the story is based on a real rivalry between the professors of that era. It is an easy read, with the emphasis being on surviving in the great outdoors and life in Wild West towns and very little about the bones. The plot itself is a bit of a stretch, relying on innumerable contrivances to enable Johnson to survive and hold on to the bones. Similar to Pirate Latitudes, it is clear why a perfectionist like Crichton did not end up publishing this during his lifetime. Though it is entertaining, it does not have the depth or polish of his famous works.

Rating: 3/5
